body:
Hi hi. I’m a noob too! I’ll attribute the bulk of my success to luck (and not having full-blown autism)

I buy plain vanilla calls/puts, no complicated option strategies.

The DTE depends on a few things for me:
1. Do I have daytrades available? If yes, I can consider same day expiring options.
2. Is there a clear tradable pattern? If yes, is it intra-day or multi-day? If it’s intra-day, can consider same day expiring options and can buy BIG (30% of account) for HUGE gains. Close trade as soon as the pattern isn’t going according to plan. If it’s a multi-day trend, can considering buying 3 to 7 trading days to expiry options. 
3. How long can I stay awake? I’m day trading from outside the states and the stock market opens at 10:30pm on my side. I try to sleep by 2 or 3am so I don’t buy same-day expiring options and stay up to monitor it unless there’s a high chance it’s gonna be a winning trade.

For winners, I hold until I no longer believe it’s going to go any higher any time soon. This can be 1 to 5 days. I monitor SPY along with 5 of the largest stocks in S&P. The chart patterns in the 5 stocks can be indicative of how SPY will move.

For losers, I don’t really hve a strategy. I will consult the charts and see if the original plan before entering the position is still valid. If it no longer is, then I’ll close it at a loss.

The idea is to look for the multi-day trend I think. Let me explain:
SPY is now in a multi-day uptrend which is in a multi-week/month downtrend. (Maybe read up on Elliot wave) So I won’t be buying puts. I will buy calls whenever the hourly trend is bearish and the candlesticks are at support. Since the market can be inexplicably erratic these days, I buy them 3 to 5 trading days out. I sell them on gapped up market opens when it seems like it’s not going to run much higher.
I sell .25-.30 delta PYPL calls on my shares around 30 DTE, long term I’m bullish on PYPL but it seems range bound so I’ll take my $800ish a month from the covered calls.
Thanks, im still experimenting with different dte
Easy to keep track of, the puts I sell on the first Friday expire on the third Friday, and vice versa. Also, I find that the premium per DTE is best when the DTE is around 15.

Theta does not decay options in a strict linear pattern. If it has Theta of 10, it's no guarantee that it will actually lower in value by $10 per day, even if the price stayed the same. Theta seems to hit harder in the range from 45 DTE to 3 or 4 DTE. It's just an average.

The other primary factor in pricing is volatility. And lastly, you have the free market as well. I can't say for sure what caused the fluctuations in yours. Occasionally, the underlying can move up or down, but you don't always see the derivatives change as equally as you'd expect, especially the deeper OTM they are.

* Dca upro, soxl and tqqq with stop loss. Adjust stop loss to 85% of current price once a month. Wait 2 weeks after stop loss triggered. Calls on big drop. Puts on big jump. 30% stop loss on options.

* Really deep itm Leap on Spy and blue chip. 30% stop loss.

* If 100 shares, sell 30 delta calls 45dte. Roll forward at 20 dte.

"30 delta call" choose the call that has a delta of 30. It will be a higher strike price than the current share price.

"45 DTE" 45 days until expiration. between 45 days and 20 days until expiration short premium strategies have the best balance between theta decay and gamma (volatility) risk

The art of this is picking the right strike.  Popular thought is that selling the .3 delta and 30-45 dte is relatively "safe."

In this crazy bullish market, you'd have to pick a fairly stable stock or write a further otm strike to capture more share price gains but less premium.

Personally, I think writing options is a great strategy.  You just have to be comfortable for price increases passed your strike.

Did a little bit of work on my model and decided to step back from 1 day forecasts two look at daily trends. So I changed my model to predict 10 steps ahead in daily time intervals using the past 5 years of historical data. If you have questions about the model look back in my comment history or post below. 

Here are the results over the past ten weeks including a forecast of the next 10 days - [https://imgur.com/a/WYsEWTL](https://imgur.com/a/WYsEWTL)

Obviously still not perfect but I think that it is much more reasonable then trying to predict the next day of price action. The shorter your time frame, the more stock prices appear to be a stochastic process, i.e., random walk. 

Looking at the 5 period MA of the daily RSI on QQQ, total Exchange Call/Put ratio, and VIX call/Put ratio, I decided to open a short position in a selection of stocks with DTE from 30-60. I don't expect I prolonged down turn put I like to give myself time incase I am early. Right now I have, or looking to get this week, puts on PYPL, QQQ, NVDA, and CSCO, all ATM.

Why I am loading the fuck up on 30-60 DTE ATM puts:

Total Exchange Call/Put Ratio - [https://imgur.com/a/MAbTNlQ](https://imgur.com/a/MAbTNlQ)

VIX Call/Put Ratio - [https://imgur.com/a/JaJ7DZA](https://imgur.com/a/JaJ7DZA)

Thats really narrow for 43 DTE, you are getting about 0.47 in theta decay, while a short strangle gets 6.0 in theta decay for a $1200 bpr. I suggest you do a short stangle instead as you get about 6% more in theta decay.

So, at Charles Schwab, there is a glitch in their system that allows you to write a spread using the monthly SPX option and the weekly SPX option expiring same day.  For example, the 5/17 monthly and the 5/17 weekly.  Because the 5/17 weekly has a longer DTE technically you will ALWAYS have a credit.  

The kicker?  Their system doesn't recognize them as two different kinds of options.  So, the 5/17 SPX monthlies are AM options and technically expire the night before... leaving you with a SHITTON of uncovered SPX 5/17 weeklies.

Would definitely not get anything with less than 10 DTE, maybe some May 17 160s or 158s depending on how much risk you want. Right now I have 5/10 158s because I'm comfortable with the risk and am pretty confident in my model, will roll out if the market pops after FOMC.

Finally the money hit my account this morning. I made 1 trade on FB. Bought 172.50 calls 0 dte 15 contracts. Closed them about an hour later for 125% gain. Small money but felt good. If I could just limit myself to a couple trades per week I think I would be much more successful. Wait for the right opportunity to present itself and not be greedy. I hope we can all identify these opportunities next week when the market open again. Take your time and form a strategy before going into next week and be ready to NOT take some trade you think you are missing out on.

theta increases as you get closer to the expiration date. thus, at the end of an option's lifespan, it's value is equal to the premium. IIRC, 3 months out is when theta starts being something that matters and 45-15 DTE is 'maximum' theta decay compared to the tradeoff on volatility.

Let’s say you think MU is done slipping.

You write 30 August $42.5p and collect $150 per contract.

You can write 145 of these, collect $21k in premium.

Sure if MU goes under $42.50 between now and 30 August you get assigned at $42.50.  Shit, MU could drop to $40 so you insta lose $2.50 per share (150 contracts times 100 shares times $2.50 plus $21k in premium so lose ofr $16.5k ), so not really risk free, but relatively low risk.

But if you keep the $21k, that is 3.5% off of $600k.  In a month.

Will he win every month?  No, he’ll get assigned, and probably actually lose money maybe half the time, but it’s low risk compared with buying 0 DTE OTM options.

MSFT ATM call, +1yr DTE (min 1yr). It’s called a leap. It’s a leveraged option, which is already leveraged. Go put it in a back tester.

5% movement in MSFT represented generally 10-20% movement in the leap. This works both up and down, but generally MSFT is growth stock.

Advantages: 
* If MSFT moves against you, you literally have a year for it to move back. 
* You don’t hold it for a year. Repeat after me DO NOT HOLD OPTIONS TO EXPIRY. My leaps last 2-3mths
* It’s leveraged as fuck. Small movements represent big gains, with relatively safe risk (see point 1)

Disadvantage:
* unlike stocks, if msft moves against you and you wait and wait, and it never recovers, you lose it all. See point 2 above. Do not hold it to expiration. Theta will murder you. Seriously, leaps are murdered by theta if you hold them too long. 
* big capital. A leap on MSFT is typically around $1.5k. You actually want to buy slightly ITM. But if you’re confident in the stock, then the risk is more buying power reduction. I typically go for $10k of leaps, but your portfolio will vary.
* Premiums matter, on a good day the leaps are expensive. Wait for a day when MSFT is going down.

Other notes:
* You can only do leaps on limited stocks and get good performance. It has to be well established, BYND even if it had chains that far out would be insane.
* Leaps are very much a set a limit and wait for a fill, do not chase an open and DO NOT DO A MARKET ORDER, FFS SAY NO TO MARKET ORDERS PEOPLE.
* It must be a growth stock (ok technically you could do it on a bear stock, but that’s risky)
* it must have volume. WM is awesome, but there just isn’t the movement. You’re not looking to carry the leap to expiration. You want in and out within a few months at most. Despite WMs growth, the needle just wouldn’t move.
* Be careful with volatile stocks. SPY is a growth stock, but it moves a lot. Way too much. 
* Backtest. If you have access to the tools, run a leap on a stock and see how it performed. That will show you that WM sucks despite growing well, and MSFT printed tendies. It’s also worth seeing how it does over a negative period. I carried leaps over May, they looked ugly as fuck during May, but in June they were clean and green.
Also remember, if you sell any calls agains the shares, the premium less closing price is taxable as ordinary income, regardless of DTE

#Dow

Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) Card applicants with 'subprime' credit scores have been receiving approval from Goldman Sachs Group (GS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage), the bank behind the card, reported CNBC. Elsewhere, 9to5mac reported that Apple mobile phone market share in Europe fell 17% year-on-year in Q2, according to Canalys data.

Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) – Iraq’s Oil Ministry said talks with Exxon on boosting the country’s oil output continue and the lack of an agreement doesn’t mean the talks have broken down, responding to media reports.

Nike (NKE) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) is entering the subscription business, with a service for children called Nike Adventure, and hinted that there could be more services to come, reported CNBC.

#NASDAQ 100

Alphabet Inc’s (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) YouTube has been accused of interfering in Russia's sovereign affairs, reported the Guardian. The video streaming platform has been accused of spreading information on unsanctioned opposition protests.

Amgen Inc. (AMGN) (Health Care/Biotechnology), Novartis (NVS) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) - A US judge upheld two patents relating to Amgen’s rheumatoid arthritis drug Enbrel, and denied a challenge by Novartis, who sought to launch a copycat version. Novartis said it would appeal the ruling.

Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) CEO Elon Musk announced that the company had pulled plans to build an air suspension option for its Model 3 vehicle.

Viacom Inc. (VIAB) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment), CBS Corp. (CBS) (Communication Services/Broadcasting) – Multiple reports suggest that a merger deal between the two co.’s is imminent and could be announced as soon as this week, after both boards met this past weekend to work out a few remaining decisions regarding board structure (CBS are slated to get 13 seats to Viacom’s 4), Leadership, Deal terms and naming.

#S&P 500

Barrick Gold Corp (GOLD) (Materials/Metals & Mining) Q2 19 (USD): adj. EPS 0.09 (exp. 0.09), Revenues 2.063bln (exp. 2.13bln), Q2 gold production 1.353mln ounces, Sees annual production at the top end of guidance range, Sees FY production at between 5.1mln-5.6mln ounces.

BlackRock’s (BLK) (Financials/Asset Management & Custody Banks) new PE fund, Long Term Private Capital, has completed a USD 875mln investment in Authentic Brands Group, becoming the largest investor in the entertainment company.

General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) and Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) see no future for hybrid vehicles in their US line-ups, reported the WSJ. Reportedly, conversely Toyota (TM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) and Ford Motor (F) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) are expanding their US hybrid offerings whilst also working on full electric models.

Theta turns positive after the midpoint of the spread, vega exposure cancels out, and gamma is back loaded rather than frontloaded. If you are strongly targeting a specific sell date, there's no reason to be buying gamma that is higher as DTE increases, nor to be bleeding more theta, or buying volatility exposure if you're making a price play.

Otherwise there are a few ways [that tastytrade also dives into in expert detail](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/options-jive/episodes/expected-move-formula-vs-strike-price-07-12-2017). The exact pricing is found using the formula (stock price) * IV * sqrt(DTE/365). Other back of the envelope methods include taking 85% of the front month straddle price, or averaging the prices of the front month straddle and the 16 delta strangle.

Vega is volatility. The long and short leg of the vertical spread are correspondingly long and short vega, and therefore movements in IV (Implied Volatility) have minimal effects on the position.

Gamma is the second order of Delta but I phrased that part incorrectly. Charm, or the change in Delta in respect to DTE (Days to Expiration), is the correct word to use. Naked calls have a decaying delta over time, which means that huge moves in the underlying have the greatest effect on the option price when you buy the call, and it decreases with every passing day.

https://www.optiontradingtips.com/images/option-charm.gif

On the other hand, vertical spreads have a very low delta far out from expiration, and as expiration approaches delta increases, which is a better tool for targeting specific future dates (cheaper to manage early on).

As for theta, spreads have positive theta as the price approaches and passes the short leg (which would be the upper bound price in a bull call spread). As you can imagine, if your max profit is at 150 and the underlying stock is currently at 160 with 20 DTE, then the position will gain value every day rather than lose value as it becomes more certain that the position will indeed close at max profit.

I can't answer your specific msft question as the msft call value depends on the share price and the strike of the call, which you didn't provide. If the call was close to expiry, then the fall in value was almost certainly theta erasing your extrinsic value in the call.

When you hold a naked call you own profit in every price level from your strike up to infinity. As you can imagine, as expiration approaches, the likelihood of the share price skyrocketing to levels far above your strike decreases at an ever accelerating rate. While there's a small chance for MSFT to hit 150 with 30DTE, there's an impossibly small chance for MSFT to jump to 150 with 2 days left. If your short leg for a bull call spread was at 140, then you never owned this outlandish possibility of profit in the first place and are not subject to its decay.

https://www.projectoption.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/ATM_Decay_Curve.svg?x34254)

In general, it's a bad idea to hold naked calls under 30 DTE unless you're strictly looking to capitalize on a parabolic upswing and corresponding IV spike, or they're part of a larger position that has some longer term exposure as well. Sometimes they're also valuable if you think a huge pop will come sometime soon but don't quite know when, and want to ensure you fully capture this movement when it does occur.

Check the historical short-term IV (e.g., try to plot a chart of ATM IV for the front month options) for the underlyings where you see this behavior. You're likely going to see that IV is higher. With higher IV, you usually have higher overall extrinsic value, which must decay until expiration. This means the options have to lose more value on the same amount of time (0-5 DTE, as in your example). That means faster decay, including faster intraday decay.

The only relatively high probability win rate is to gain from IV:

* buy weeks before, sell right before earnings (long IV)
* sell strangles (or iron condors) right before earnings with closest DTE possible and wait (short IV). IC less risk but less premium than ICs.  Strangles work well *most* of the times (GOOG, AMZN, SQ, TWTR etc..), but in the rare case (e.g TSLA's last earnings), an IC would be the only way to protect you and strangles could wipe out all the gains you made in the past few months and then some..

Do NOT buy right before earnings. IV crush will kill you. If you want to buy, do it much earlier with a relatively long DTE like you would for usual options.

Essentially if you look at outstanding options on SPY you can see that in order for the currently outstanding options to remain delta neutral (most market makers objectives) they will have to flip their positions from long to short or short to long at these levels. Thus fueling the moves that would push them through such levels in the first place.  


If market makers sell 1,000 calls with delta of 0.8, then they buy 80,000 shares to remain delta neutral.  


If market sells and delta falls to say 0.5 then they have to re balance accordingly to remain delta neutral. In this scenario the market maker would be forced to sell 62.5% of its shares that were originally purchased in order to accommodate the change in delta. (0.5/0.8=62.5%)

If market than rallied afterword market maker would have to add shares to positions as delta increased.  


Essentially you can think about it as an asymptotic relationship where the need to purchase / sell shares in order to remain delta neutral increases as you approach these price points, and the need to do so decreases the closer you are to the median of these points.  


Vix will pop as you cross over these points and fall as you get closer to the median of these points. The data is calculated using options with less than 100 DTE.
IV is kinda like: (delta/OI)*DTE)+asking price... it helps when your trying to calculate how much money you want to lose for the day.

You clearly don't know what your talking about. (I'm not surprised, most people here don't even know what option writing is). If you don't understand why a purchaser of put/call options is buying insurance. Then you need to take your series 7 again.

Lets go through the basics again.

A put is a right, but not an obligation to sell stock by the expired date.

A call is a right but not an obligation to buy stock by the expired date.

Why are purchasers of this contract considered buying insurance? Because the writer (aka underwiter) is guaranteeing to you (the purchaser) that should the stock fall below the strike (in the case of puts) that they will buy your stock at an agreed upon price. This is insurance my friend. I, the option writer, is guaranteeing your max loss is defined by the difference in strike price of the contract plus the premium.

Now on the call side why is this also insurance? Because lets say your an airline and you want to ensure that your fuel costs are fixed. Should the price of the fuel rise by 5%, your suddenly unprofitable. So what do you do? You buy call options. Again I the option writer of calls is guaranteeing that you can acquire fuel at a maximum fixed cost. Now what do I get for taking on such a risk? Premium. Its not by accident that its called premium.

Next. As an option writer you should know the key differences between undefined risk and defined risk. Lets go over the basics again. Selling a put is considered "defined risk" that is no matter what price the share goes to (even zero) there is a defined risk. So long as you cash secure this transaction there is NO MARGIN requirement. For the call side, if you sell naked calls there is what we call "undefined risk". The losses could be unlimited. Now why did James Cordier blow up his fund? Its because he engaged in naked call selling. What is the lesson here? DO NOT SELL NAKED CALLS PERIOD. If you have to, you better be prepared to cover quickly.

Now after having explained to you the basics why do option writers win over the long run?

A couple reasons.

1. Options pricing is based on the  **Black**\-**Scholes**  (if you exclude LEAPS) pricing model. This means that you are theta positive. As time progresses you have an ever increasing burden to meet the break even point as a buyer. Especially so during the 5 DTE period.
2. In the event of assignment, you are either giving away stock you own, or buying stock in which you cash secured. Now you have the option to take the opposite position (either writing a call or put). Eventually you will recover your acb and more and turn a losing position to an immensely profitable one.
3. You only underwrite good companies. Just like an insurance carrier only writes good drivers. So too should you. This means that even if your saddled with shares, you want them anyway in the long run. This is a very risk adverse strategy. Dont believe me, why don't you have a chat with the big guy Warren Buffet.

Next time you want to talk shit about option writing you better put your money where your mouth is.
